title: Hey look, Part 5
body: This story ran in Friday's edition of the Drury Mirror. Very nice write up, if I might say so myself... but you don't have to take my word for it. < cut to a butterfly flying past a rainbow > Butterfly in the sky I can fly twice as high It's in a book So take a look A reading rainbow! Springfield Gets Moxie By Hayley Budd Drury Mirror, February 18, 2005 When was the last time you saw a foreign film at a theater here in Springfield? Do you remember that we barely got to see movies like Bowling For Columbine and Sideways? Oscar-nominated films such as Maria Full of Grace and The Motorcycle Diaries don't stand a chance here, and we lose out. Enter The Moxie. The Moxie is Springfield's newest independent movie theater dedicated to showing the great movies that don't make it to our city including documentaries, foreign films, and local films by local filmmakers. Located at 408 W. Walnut with a projected opening date of late March, The Moxie will be similar to Columbia's Ragtag Cinemacafe. "We're almost like Ragtag's sister theater," Dan Chilton, owner, said, because Ragtag was "the spark that started the Moxie." Dan and Nicole Chilton want their theater to be strongly connected to the community. Originally from Springfield, they decided several years ago that what their hometown needed was an art house theater and that maybe, if they were "lucky", they would be the people to open one. Since its beginning, the theater has relied on local businesses to play a role in its completion. The beer and wine served at the theater will be local or at least regional, coming from the Springfield Brewing Company or Boulevard Brew Co. In addition, the Mudhouse is developing a special coffee blend, Fitz's of St. Louis will provide the sodas, and Andy's Custard has a signature "Moxie" flavor in the works. The Chilton's commitment to the community does not stop there. Local artists will be able to show their work in the hallways and perhaps the auditorium of the theater, and the canned-in music will be by local bands. Also, The Moxie will play host to film festivals and showings organized in conjunction with local university language and film clubs. "We want to cater to the community," Chilton said, "and add personality to the experience." Dr. Maxim Matusevich, Drury Cinema Club sponsor, is looking forward to collaborating on festivals with The Moxie, "That would be totally fantabulous. I expect that The Moxie and Drury Cinema Club (as well as the SMS movie series) will end up working closely together. The more the merrier." Long-term plans for The Moxie include the possibility of a change in location: "We're always keeping an eye out to upgrade," Chilton said. Also, the Moxie might expand into nearby communities. "There are plenty of towns around here that could use this kind of theater," Chilton said. The cost of a single ticket will be $8, $6.50 for students and seniors, $5 for a matinee showing, and $5 for late showings and specials. Schedules for the theater will be posted online, printed on a monthly calendar, and available via moviephone. The Moxie should open in late March after general repairs to the building are finished, licensing and permits are secured, framing is raised, the projection booth is built, seating is installed, and finishing touches are made. Visit the Moxie Blog at www.blog.moxiecinema.com for more information and regular updates on the progress of the theater.
